channel.title: KQED's The California Report
channel.description: KQED's statewide half-hour radio news program, providing daily coverage of issues, trends and public policy decisions affecting California and its diverse population.
channel.itunes:subtitle: KQED's statewide half-hour radio news program, providing daily coverage of issues, trends and public policy decisions affecting California and its diverse population.

item.title: Mixed Record in Sacramento on Gun Control Laws; New Calls For Further Limits
item.description: California is known for having some of the strictest gun control laws in the nation. But last week's mass shooting in San Bernardino has legislators calling for new laws to regulate firearms even more. The results of recent gun control efforts present a more nuanced picture than California's anti-gun reputation suggests.
item.itunes:subtitle: California is known for having some of the strictest gun control laws in the nation. But last week's mass shooting in San Bernardino has legislators calling for new laws to regulate firearms even more. The results of recent gun control efforts present a m

item.dc:creator: Marisa Lagos

item.title: Vital Signs: Promotoras de Salud Guide Immigrants Through the Health Care System
item.description: Immigrant families sometimes have a harder time navigating the health care system. That's where "promotoras de salud" come in. These Spanish-speaking health educators go door to door, connecting residents to community clinics and other services to improve well-being. Today we hit the streets with a promotora in Hayward, near Oakland.

item.title: Supreme Court Case Could Impact Political Clout of State's Latinos
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court hears a case Tuesday that gets to the heart of what it means to have representative government. The challenge to 'one person, one vote' could affect the political clout of Latinos in California. It comes down to this: do elected officials represent everyone who lives in their district, or only the people eligible to vote?
item.itunes:subtitle: The U.S. Supreme Court hears a case Tuesday that gets to the heart of what it means to have representative government. The challenge to 'one person, one vote' could affect the political clout of Latinos in California. It comes down to this: do elected off
item.itunes:summary: The U.S. Supreme Court hears a case Tuesday that gets to the heart of what it means to have representative government. The challenge to 'one person, one vote' could affect the political clout of Latinos in California. It comes down to this: do elected officials represent everyone who lives in their district, or only the people eligible to vote?
item.dc:creator: Scott Shafer

item.title: L.A. Sues Gas Company Over Porter Ranch Leak
item.description: Los Angeles City Attorney Mike Feuer filed a lawsuit against Southern California Gas Company on Monday. At issue is a natural gas leak at the company's Aliso Canyon facility. It's been leaking for over a month -- and the lawsuit claims the utility didn't notify residents immediately, and wasn't prepared to stop it. Fumes from the leak have sickened residents of Porter Ranch, who have suffered from nose bleeds, headaches and nausea. About 700 families have had to move out of their homes.
item.itunes:subtitle: Los Angeles City Attorney Mike Feuer filed a lawsuit against Southern California Gas Company on Monday. At issue is a natural gas leak at the company's Aliso Canyon facility. It's been leaking for over a month -- and the lawsuit claims the utility didn't

Fumes from the leak have sickened residents of Porter Ranch, who have suffered from nose bleeds, headaches and nausea. About 700 families have had to move out of their homes.
item.dc:creator: Queena Kim

item.title: Religious Leaders Gather for Interfaith Vigil in San Bernardino
item.description: The federal investigation continues into the two shooters responsible for last week's massacre in San Bernardino. Meanwhile, religious leaders from across the region joined together Monday night for an interfaith service to remember the victims of the mass shooting, and to send a message that there is no room for anti-Muslim sentiment in the community.
item.itunes:subtitle: The federal investigation continues into the two shooters responsible for last week's massacre in San Bernardino. Meanwhile, religious leaders from across the region joined together Monday night for an interfaith service to remember the victims of the mas

Meanwhile, religious leaders from across the region joined together Monday night for an interfaith service to remember the victims of the mass shooting, and to send a message that there is no room for anti-Muslim sentiment in the community.
item.dc:creator: Steven Cuevas

item.title: Renaissance Fair Performers Remember One of Their Own, Lost in San Bernardino Shooting
item.description: Over the weekend, we've been learning some details about the 14 people killed in last Wednesday's mass shooting in San Bernardino. Larry Daniel Kaufman was one of those victims. Some described him as a bit of a "jester," because in his free time, Kaufman performed at the Renaissance Pleasure Faire in Irwindale, east of Los Angeles.

item.title: Charter School Controversy Heats Up in Los Angeles and Oakland
item.description: Oakland and Los Angeles have more charter schools than any other city in California. Now, there's a push to enroll even more students in charter schools in those cities -- and it's being led by some very wealthy education reformers. Traditional public school advocates are fighting back.
item.itunes:subtitle: Oakland and Los Angeles have more charter schools than any other city in California. Now, there's a push to enroll even more students in charter schools in those cities -- and it's being led by some very wealthy education reformers. Traditional public sch

Traditional public school advocates are fighting back.
item.dc:creator: Ana Tintocalis

item.title: Pigeon Pageant
item.description: A nearly 70-year-old pageant has just come to a close in California and its contestants arent your normal beauty queens. Theyre pigeons. And they were on full display at the Los Angeles Pigeon Clubs annual Pageant of the Pigeons." Its like a dog show for pigeons. Reporter Susan Valot met some of these feathered friends and the people who love them.

item.title: Reflecting on San Bernardino
item.description: San Bernardino is nestled below a mountain range, and sits just off the I-10 freeway. It's the sort of place Southern Californians zoom by on their way to Palm Springs or Las Vegas. But this week's mass shootings have put a spotlight on the city. In the 1990s, it was known as a "murder capital," and gun violence remains stubbornly high. It's struggled with high rates of poverty and in 2012, the city filed for bankruptcy. Our Los Angeles Bureau Chief Steven Cuevas lived in the region for years, and has been covering the events of this week. We talk with him about how residents there are feeling.
item.itunes:subtitle: San Bernardino is nestled below a mountain range, and sits just off the I-10 freeway. It's the sort of place Southern Californians zoom by on their way to Palm Springs or Las Vegas. But this week's mass shootings have put a spotlight on the city. In the 1
item.itunes:summary: San Bernardino is nestled below a mountain range, and sits just off the I-10 freeway. It's the sort of place Southern Californians zoom by on their way to Palm Springs or Las Vegas. But this week's mass shootings have put a spotlight on the city. In the 1990s, it was known as a "murder capital," and gun violence remains stubbornly high. It's struggled with high rates of poverty and in 2012, the city filed for bankruptcy. Our Los Angeles Bureau Chief Steven Cuevas lived in the region for years, and has been covering the events of this week. We talk with him about how residents there are feeling.
item.dc:creator: KQED Staff

item.title: California Muslim Groups Respond to San Bernardino Shooting
item.description: While the city of San Bernardino hosted a vigil on Thursday, in the nearby city of Chino members of the Baitul Hameed Mosque held their own gathering to mourn the 14 people who were killed and to pray for the 21 wounded victims. Condemnations and prayer vigils have become an almost immediate response by Muslim leaders in the wake of attacks perpetrated in the name of Islam. But some Muslims, particularly in Northern California, have been rethinking this strategy.
item.itunes:subtitle: While the city of San Bernardino hosted a vigil on Thursday, in the nearby city of Chino members of the Baitul Hameed Mosque held their own gathering to mourn the 14 people who were killed and to pray for the 21 wounded victims. Condemnations and prayer v

Condemnations and prayer vigils have become an almost immediate response by Muslim leaders in the wake of attacks perpetrated in the name of Islam. But some Muslims, particularly in Northern California, have been rethinking this strategy.
item.dc:creator: Queena Kim

item.title: Where Are All the Hanukkah Songs?
item.description: If you've been to a shopping mall or turned on the radio in the past couple weeks, chances are you?ve heard "Let It Snow," "Winter Wonderland," "White Christmas" or "Silver Bells." What do all those songs all have in common? Besides being ubiquitous this time of year, they were all written by Jewish composers. With the first night of Hanukkah beginning Sunday, we wondered: if Jews are writing all the Christmas classics, who's writing the Hanukkah songs?
item.itunes:subtitle: If you've been to a shopping mall or turned on the radio in the past couple weeks, chances are you?ve heard "Let It Snow," "Winter Wonderland," "White Christmas" or "Silver Bells." What do all those songs all have in common? Besides being ubiquitous this

item.dc:creator: Avishay Artsy

item.title: Pageant of the Pigeons Celebrates a Much-Maligned Creature
item.description: A nearly 70-year-old pageant has just come to a close in Southern California, and its contestants aren't your typical beauty queens. The Los Angeles Pigeon Club's annual "Pageant of the Pigeons" is kind of like a dog show for these much-maligned creatures. We meet some of these feathered friends and the people who love them.

item.title: Bay Area High School Choirs Face Off in 'American Idol'-Style Sing-Off
item.description: The musical competition has been with us for a long, long time, but "American Idol" took the form to a whole new level, reaching highs and lows never seen before. The show is about to air its final season, but over the course of 15 years, its phenomenal popularity has inspired a host of TV shows, movies and real life competitions, like a high school choir sing-off going on right now in the San Francisco Bay Area. And your vote could determine who wins.

item.title: Parents of Surviving San Bernardino Victim: 'It's a Blessing'
item.description: Twenty-four-year-old Kevin Ortiz is a health inspector who was shot five times in Wednesday's rampage. His family has chosen not to share details of the attack with him as he recovers.
item.itunes:subtitle: Twenty-four-year-old Kevin Ortiz is a health inspector who was shot five times in Wednesday's rampage. His family has chosen not to share details of the attack with him as he recovers.

item.dc:creator: Brian Watt

item.title: Victims of Shooting Memorialized in San Bernardino Vigils
item.description: The victims of this week's mass shooting were memorialized Thursday night at a pair of vigils, the largest at a minor league baseball stadium not far from where 14 people were killed at the Inland Regional Center.
item.itunes:subtitle: The victims of this week's mass shooting were memorialized Thursday night at a pair of vigils, the largest at a minor league baseball stadium not far from where 14 people were killed at the Inland Regional Center.

item.title: Police Identify 2 Suspects in San Bernardino Massacre
item.description: Law enforcement officials continue to work around the clock investigating the rampage that left 14 dead and more than a dozen wounded in San Bernardino on Wednesday. Authorities have identified the two suspects who were later shot and killed in a shootout with law enforcement.
item.itunes:subtitle: Law enforcement officials continue to work around the clock investigating the rampage that left 14 dead and more than a dozen wounded in San Bernardino on Wednesday. Authorities have identified the two suspects who were later shot and killed in a shootout
item.itunes:summary: Law enforcement officials continue to work around the clock investigating the rampage that left 14 dead and more than a dozen wounded in San Bernardino on Wednesday. Authorities have identified the two suspects who were later shot and killed in a shootout with law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Steven Cuevas

item.title: The Story Behind the Inland Regional Center, Site of San Bernardino Massacre
item.description: The San Bernardino shooting happened within the Inland Regional Center. The center serves adults and children with developmental disabilities. The main attack appears to have happened during a holiday party in a large conference room used by an unrelated group. Still, the shooting brings focus to these centers and the vulnerable population they serve.
item.itunes:subtitle: The San Bernardino shooting happened within the Inland Regional Center. The center serves adults and children with developmental disabilities. The main attack appears to have happened during a holiday party in a large conference room used by an unrelated

Still, the shooting brings focus to these centers and the vulnerable population they serve.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Aliferis

item.title: State and National Democrats Call for Further Gun Control
item.description: The horrific scene in San Bernardino was still playing out when prominent Democrats began talking about the need for stricter gun control laws. President Obama, Hillary Clinton and Sen. Dianne Feinstein were among the national figures saying the massacre in San Bernardino should spur Congress into action.
item.itunes:subtitle: The horrific scene in San Bernardino was still playing out when prominent Democrats began talking about the need for stricter gun control laws. President Obama, Hillary Clinton and Sen. Dianne Feinstein were among the national figures saying the massacre

item.title: L.A. County Tries to Boost Outreach to Convicted Felons in Wake of Prop. 47
item.description: Under Proposition 47 passed last year, more than 700,000 convicted felons in L.A. County are eligible to have their non-violent crimes downgraded to misdemeanors. But fewer than 50,000 have applied, leaving the rest unable to access a host of rehab services. An ordinance approved Tuesday by L.A. County supervisors aims to help eligible felons connect with legal aid, job help and other services.
item.itunes:subtitle: Under Proposition 47 passed last year, more than 700,000 convicted felons in L.A. County are eligible to have their non-violent crimes downgraded to misdemeanors. But fewer than 50,000 have applied, leaving the rest unable to access a host of rehab servic

item.dc:creator: Steven Cuevas

item.title: Sacramento District Uses Home Visits to Connect Teachers With Kids and Their Families
item.description: The low-tech parent-teacher home visit is making a comeback in California. That's because it's proving to be a good way for teachers to build relationships with families -- and that can radically improve what happens in the classroom. A project based in Sacramento City Unified School District is leading the country in this area.

item.title: Silicon Valley Titans Back New Clean Energy Initiative
item.description: Later this week, Gov. Jerry Brown will head to the international climate conference in Paris where he'll tout California's leadership in curbing greenhouse gas emissions. High-tech titans from California are also hopping on the green energy bandwagon. They're lining up to support a new clean energy initiative announced by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

item.title: California Cities Build Momentum on Minimum Wage Boosts
item.description: It's a debate that's been going on for years in the U.S. What is the minimum amount an American worker should make? Increasing concerns about income inequality have given that debate a tone of urgency. Now, cities have started making the minimum wage policies that states and the federal government have traditionally made -- and about half of the nation's recent minimum wage hikes have been in California.
item.itunes:subtitle: It's a debate that's been going on for years in the U.S. What is the minimum amount an American worker should make? Increasing concerns about income inequality have given that debate a tone of urgency. Now, cities have started making the minimum wage poli

item.title: Big Think: Making Psychedelics Mainstream
item.description: In our continuing series "Big Think," we meet a man who?s researching the use of psychedelic drugs to treat mental illnesses. Rick Doblin leads a Santa Cruz nonprofit that sponsors research using LSD and MDMA to treat treat post-traumatic stress disorder among war veterans. They're studying how LSD can help ease the dying process for the terminally ill.

item.title: Special: 'Love in the Digital Age'
item.description: Today, we present a special holiday edition exploring the wide variety of ways we love in the digital age. We say grace over FaceTime with a South Bay family separated by the Mexican border and U.S. immigration law. We'll dive deep into the difficult teenage years with a family in Berkeley, and talk to a mom who used her daughter's smartphone to keep tabs on her. And we'll meet a couple in Fremont who only met after their parents met each other -- using a matrimonial web site.

item.description: Like It or Not, Wild Turkeys Proliferate in East Bay. Paper or Plastic?.

item.itunes:summary: Like It or Not, Wild Turkeys Proliferate in East Bay. Paper or Plastic?.

item.title: Like It or Not, Wild Turkeys Proliferate in East Bay
item.description: Once upon a time, they were only seen on Thanksgiving Day. But these days in the Bay Area, the guest of honor on your holiday table is part of everyday life whether you like it or not.
item.itunes:subtitle: Once upon a time, they were only seen on Thanksgiving Day. But these days in the Bay Area, the guest of honor on your holiday table is part of everyday life whether you like it or not.

item.dc:creator: Tena Rubio

item.title: Paper or Plastic?
item.description: The drought in California has one small town taking unusual measures to conserve water. Fort Bragg city officials have asked local restaurants to cut down on dishwashing by serving meals on paper plates with plastic utensils.
item.itunes:subtitle: The drought in California has one small town taking unusual measures to conserve water. Fort Bragg city officials have asked local restaurants to cut down on dishwashing by serving meals on paper plates with plastic utensils.

item.title: The California Report

item.title: Lake County Kids Ready for Something to Celebrate After Valley Fire
item.description: Thanksgiving is different this year for families in Lake County who are still dealing with the aftermath of September's destructive Valley Fire. We caught up with some kids at Lake County International Charter School to find out how they'll be celebrating the holiday.

item.dc:creator: Sukey Lewis

item.title: The Power of Gratitude to Help a Damaged Heart
item.description: It's a time for a lot of us to reflect on just how thankful we are for what we have -- friends, families, our health. And now, psychologists at UC San Diego are adding to a growing body of research that shows how learning and expressing gratitude can be good for our health.
